Today we're not making spaghetti carbonara.
Some might say it looks like carbonara, and tastes like carbonara, and has the mouthfeel of carbonara, the substances which make up carbonara, and even the personality of carbonara.
But this is not carbonara.
The first thing we're gonna do is chop up some bacon.
That's how you know this isn't carbonara, because if you were making carbonara, you'd be using guanciale.
You see, bacon comes from a pig, whereas guanciale comes from a completely different animal, known as an Italian hog.
Oh my god, it looks like a jumping Italian horse!
You wouldn't make a hamburger with tiger meat, would you?
I really hope not.
Tigers are expensive.
Carbonara is typically made with egg yolks, which is irrelevant, since that's not what we're making.
Don't accidentally use egg yolkles, because banjo music really ruins this dish.
We'll just do the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick.
You can also do the back and forth, and whoops, maybe no forth.
Then make the traditional Italian egg white on toast as an appetizer.
Mmm.
This is pecorino romano, which you would use if you're making carbonara, which we are not.
It gets its name because the Romans who made it had huge pecs.
So did the goats.
They worked out together.
If you want to shred your pecorino more easily, you can take a drill, put in a nice big fat screw, then you just... okay.
So, whoop.
All right.
If I just maybe... okay, let's try.
Nope.
See, in my mind when I thought of this, none of the physics of how objects work would be an issue.
If you're Italian, you don't need to innovate in this department, because you simply harness the power of your hand gesture muscles, which makes this a breeze.
So grate that into the egg yolk and wang jangle until you've got Cadbury cream egg filling.
Then we'll add some pepper pepper pepper, and we're good to go.
And by go, I mean stay, because we're not done yet.
The original carbonara was made with handcrafted artisan spaghetti from the Veneto region.
Each spaghetti craftsperson had their signature style.
Sadly, these days you can only find straight parallel line spaghetti.
And you know, it just really angers me that the craft has been left to die like nobody cares.
Now let's just fix that.
Breaking spaghetti in half is a crime in Italy and can land you in prison for up to nine months.
It sounds like an overreaction at first, but the crack sends a shock wave through the noodle, rendering it completely inedible.
I mean look, here's uncracked spaghetti and cracked spaghetti.
If I didn't tell you that was spaghetti, you wouldn't have even recognized it.
Now we'll salt this angry water, then throw in 156 pieces of spaghetti.
Keep wang jangling that for the first bit to keep the spag from getting clingy.
By the way, spaghetti gets its name because you put it in the spa to cook it.
Now our bacon is cooked.
We're turning the burner off, waiting for this to cool, at least until there's no sizzle left, and a bit longer so we don't overcook the eggbased sauce.
Now I'm gonna put in a bit of pasta water into our sauce ingredients to get that cheeseahead start on the melting.
Noodles go straight from the water into the bacon pan for a wang jangulation.

Since noodles are made of wheat, this is essentially a bacon sandwich, but if you do strain the spaghetti, make sure to set aside some pasta water, and if you get the kind of spaghetti with dehydrated meatballs, just pull those out and set them aside.

Then the sauce can go in and the egg will cook just enough from the noodle heat, although you can put your pan on low to thicken it as well, because here comes more pasta water making this nice and creamy.
The reason we add pasta water is so that if you get thirsty while you eat it, you don't have to stop and have a drink.
Here I'm trying to do that fancy twist thing, but it's not the right tool, and I don't know what I'm doing.
We'll finish with some pepper pepper pepper and some more pecorino or parmesan, and here we don't have carbonara.
If you want to really see not carbonara, here's an earlier attempt where I used whole egg.
Too much heat, and for some reason this came out way worse than my first attempt with whole egg, which came out great.
So are the whims of the food gods.
If this was carbonara, you'd have to be careful, because the carbonistic properties are so fragile that if you put in a single pea, it would no longer be carbonara.
It's a mysterious chemical reaction that only Italian scientists understand.
I'm craving carbonara, but I don't have guanciale.
Should I really even bother?
Oh no, will they judge my carbonara?
Because I want some cream upon it.
Should I eat it in the closet?
Oh no, what have I done?
I've added peas to a dish that is otherwise vegetable free.
They say it's no game.
Hang my head as I eat this not carbonara in shame.

steps: Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.
Boil water in a pot and add salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.
Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk mixture, stirring quickly to coat the pasta and create a creamy sauce.
Add more reserved pasta water if needed to achieve the desired sauce consistency.
Finish with additional black pepper and grated pecorino romano cheese before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-1
outcome: Egg yolks separated and placed in a bowl
Grated pecorino romano cheese added to egg yolks
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl. Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Egg yolks are used in carbonara to create a creamy sauce. Pecorino Romano cheese adds flavor to the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the classic hold the yolk with your thumb trick or the back and forth method to separate the yolks. Grate the cheese using hand gestures for ease.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-2
outcome: Bacon is cooked until crispy and cooled slightly.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cooling the bacon slightly prevents overcooking the egg-based sauce when it is added later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Wait until there's no sizzle left before proceeding to ensure the bacon is cool enough.

steps: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil.
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Whisk the grated cheese into the egg mixture until combined.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Turn off the heat under the bacon pan and add the cooked spaghetti to the pan.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
If needed, add a little reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon.

So for this video, of course, I could have ordered guanciale, but I know most of my audience is American, so I want the most people possible to actually make this, so we're gonna use bacon. And thickcut bacon would be best. You could also use pancetta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-1
materials: Half a pound of thick-cut bacon
outcome: Bacon is crispy and fat is rendered out
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces. Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil. Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Rendering out the fat from the bacon makes it crispy, which is desirable for the texture and flavor in the pasta carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Turn the bacon occasionally to ensure even cooking and prevent burning.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
outcome: Pasta water is seasoned with salt
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water is seasoned with less salt than usual because there are many salty elements in carbonara.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-3
outcome: Grated cheese
Egg and cheese mixture with pepper
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese. In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks. Whisk the grated cheese into the egg mixture until combined. Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The cheese and egg mixture forms the base of the carbonara sauce, which will coat the pasta. The pepper adds flavor to the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a fine grater for the cheese to ensure it incorporates well into the egg mixture. Adjust the amount of pepper to your taste preference.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-1
outcome: Some bacon is set aside for garnish
Most of the bacon fat is drained, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Leaving some bacon fat in the pan will add flavor to the pasta carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Be careful not to overcook the bacon. Turn off the heat before draining the fat.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
outcome: Spaghetti cooked to slightly al dente
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cook the spaghetti in boiling water for about 10 minutes until it is slightly al dente.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Cooking the spaghetti to slightly al dente ensures it is firm enough to hold its shape and texture when mixed with the sauce later.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use a timer to ensure the spaghetti is cooked for exactly 10 minutes to achieve the desired texture.

subgoal_summaries.title: Add Egg Mixture-6
materials: Bacon pan with rendered bacon fat
outcome: Spaghetti is coated with a creamy sauce made from eggs and cheese without scrambling the eggs
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the heat under the bacon pan and add the cooked spaghetti to the pan. Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs. If needed, add a little reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The heat from the spaghetti will gently cook the eggs, creating a creamy sauce without scrambling them. Adding pasta water helps emulsify the sauce and adjust its consistency.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off to prevent scrambling the eggs. Stir gently to avoid breaking the pasta. Use reserved pasta water to adjust the sauce consistency if it's too thick.
tools: Tongs for transferring spaghetti and stirring

subgoal_summaries.title: Garnish and Serve-7
outcome: Pasta is plated with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon on top.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Plate the pasta by using tongs to transfer it to a serving dish. Sprinkle additional grated Parmigiano Reggiano cheese over the top, and add crispy bacon pieces for garnish.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding extra cheese and bacon enhances the flavor and texture, providing a creamy and crunchy contrast that complements the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pasta is plated neatly using tongs to avoid breaking it. Adding the cheese and bacon just before serving keeps them fresh and crispy.

steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta into the boiling water to prevent sticking and cook for 8 minutes.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
Crush black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorns.
Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add about 20 grams of pecorino cheese, then whisk together.
Turn off the heat under the guanciale and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot to the pan, including some pasta water.
Stir the pasta with the guanciale and fat, adding more pasta water to create an emulsion.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta off the heat, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
Finish the dish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino cheese before serving.

subgoals.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-6
subgoals.text: Now, let's get on to the eggs. Eggs are really, really delicate and if you don't treat these right, you end up with stirfried noodles and we don't want that. I'm gonna take a bowl and I'm gonna crack the egg straight into there and I'm just gonna add a little pecorino to that. So, like 20 grams.
original_steps: Crack eggs into a bowl and add about 20 grams of pecorino cheese, then whisk together.

subgoals.title: Prepare Meat-7
subgoals.text: Now, we're time sensitive so we're gonna have a little whisk up. We've got dark guanciale. We've got the fat that's come out of it and that's what you want. You want attitude and colour. Now, I'm gonna remove that garlic.
original_steps: Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.

subgoals.title: Combine Pasta and Meat-8
subgoals.text: Turn the heat off and you're gonna drag the pasta and the water into the pan. Use the water to stop the frying. Bit of water, bit of water. That water and the fat, that is what's going to emulsify to become a creamy sauce. We're not frying anymore. Can you hear that? Quiet. No frying at all.
original_steps: Turn off the heat under the guanciale and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot to the pan, including some pasta water.
Stir the pasta with the guanciale and fat, adding more pasta water to create an emulsion.

subgoals.title: Add Egg Mixture-9
subgoals.text: Only then can we think about adding our egg. As we toss, we add some more liquid. That's the cream. You get the cream through the emulsification of the cooking water and the fat and technique and timing. So, as simple as this is, it's technical. Get your friends, your family, get them around the table. Glass of wine. Look at that guys, look at that.
original_steps: Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta off the heat, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.

subgoals.title: Garnish and Serve-10
subgoals.text: Carbonara and you finish with more pepper. I'm so excited. Spaghetti, carbonara with a beautiful little finishing of pecorino. That is as classic as I can give you guys, from chefs, from nonnas. It's about quality ingredients, the guanciale, the pecorino romana, quality eggs, the pepper, the technique of the pepper, good pasta and then the sensitivity of cooking it right. Come on. There's a little platter for two people and of course, the most important thing when you eat pasta is don't watch it, eat it. Mmm. That my friends, is a thing of joy.
original_steps: Finish the dish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino cheese before serving.

subgoal_summaries.title: Gather Ingredients-1
materials: Pecorino Romano cheese (sheep's cheese, crumbly, salty)
outcome: Ingredients are gathered and ready for making Pasta Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: These are the essential ingredients needed to make an authentic Pasta Carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Try to get guanciale with the fat intact as it is needed for the dish.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-2
materials: Pasta: Long strands of pasta, such as spaghetti, used for the dish.
Salt: A small amount is added to the boiling water.
outcome: Pasta is cooked and does not stick together.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Grab the pasta by two hands, twist it into the boiling water, and cook for 8 minutes.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Twisting the pasta into the water prevents it from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Put a tiny amount of salt in the water because the cheese and guanciale are salty.
tools: Pot: Used to boil the water for cooking the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-3
outcome: Guanciale is prepared and ready for cooking
Garlic is added to the pan for flavor infusion
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks. Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat. Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pan is initially cold to allow the fat to render out slowly from the guanciale. The garlic is added to infuse its flavor into the fat as it renders.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pan is cold before adding the guanciale to properly render the fat. Crack the garlic to release more flavor.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
outcome: Hotter inner part of the peppercorns is sifted and ready to use
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Crush black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to separate the hotter inner part from the milder outer skin.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The inner part of the peppercorn is hotter and perfect for a good hot carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: This step is important and often overlooked, as the outer skin is much milder.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-3
materials: Guanciale, which is the cured cheek of pork, golden in color
Garlic, which was previously added to the pan
outcome: Garlic is removed from the pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The garlic is removed after the guanciale is golden to prevent it from overpowering the dish with its flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the guanciale is golden before removing the garlic to achieve the right flavor balance.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-4
outcome: Egg and pecorino cheese mixture
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Crack the eggs into a bowl and add about 20 grams of pecorino cheese, then whisk them together.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Eggs are delicate and need to be treated carefully to avoid ending up with stir-fried noodles instead of a creamy sauce.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-3
outcome: Garlic is removed from the pan
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Remove the garlic from the pan.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The garlic is removed after the guanciale is golden to prevent it from overpowering the dish with its flavor.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the guanciale is golden before removing the garlic to achieve the right flavor balance.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Meat-8
materials: Guanciale: Cured cheek of pork, known for its fat content.
Pasta: Cooked pasta, directly from the pot.
Pasta water: Water used to cook the pasta, added to the pan.
outcome: Pasta is combined with guanciale and fat, creating a base for the sauce.
An emulsion is formed with pasta water and fat, leading to a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Turn off the heat under the guanciale and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot to the pan, including some pasta water. Stir the pasta with the guanciale and fat, adding more pasta water to create an emulsion.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta water and fat emulsify to create a creamy sauce, which is essential for the carbonara.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Use the pasta water to stop the frying process and help create the emulsion. Ensure the heat is off to prevent frying the pasta.
tools: Pan: Used to cook the guanciale and mix with pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Add Egg Mixture-9
outcome: A creamy carbonara sauce without scrambled eggs
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Add the egg and pecorino mixture to the pasta off the heat, stirring quickly while adding some of the reserved cooking water to create a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The combination of the egg mixture, cooking water, and rendered fat emulsifies to form a creamy sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the heat is off before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling. Stir quickly and add cooking water gradually to achieve the right consistency.
tools: Bowl for mixing eggs and cheese

subgoal_summaries.title: Garnish and Serve-10
outcome: The dish is finished with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino cheese before serving.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Finish the dish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino cheese before serving.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Adding more pepper and pecorino cheese enhances the flavor and presentation of the dish, making it more authentic and delicious.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pepper is freshly cracked for the best flavor, and use high-quality pecorino cheese for authenticity.

metadata.title: How to Make Classic Carbonara | Jamie Oliver

subtitles.text: I am Antonio Carluccio.
Welcome to my kitchen.
I show you how to make the real Carbonara.
Most of the people, they get it wrong, and I will show you why.
Now, this is boiling water to which we add in the ratio of 10 grams per liter of water, salt.
Has to be like this.
And immediately then, we put in, has to be boiling, a pasta.
In this case, it's sort of spaghettoni, the biggest size of spaghetti.
While this is cooking, it takes good 10 minutes, and no oil, please.
No oil, because you don't need it.
You just need to stir a little bit when it's in it, and that's it.
Now, for the original Carbonara, you need the guanciale, which is the cheek, the pork cheek.
And the Romans, they're very special in that because they do it, they cure it like ham, or like pancetta, and it's very tender, very tasty and tender.
Now, you have to cut it in chunks.
You can use naturally also pancetta, the normal pancetta, which is this one here.
But I like the guanciale when I have it, obviously.
And this is the recipe for two people.
Big chunks.
The Romans, they are mad for this pasta.
If there is a Roman pasta, it is this one here.
This is quite a lot for two people, let's see.
And the only thing you have to do now to make the sauce is to take good olive oil, put it in the pan.
There you are.
Put the guanciale into that, and this is the beginning of the sauce, and mostly also the end of it.
Because the rest is coming here into that bowl.
And now you take some good eggs, and for two people you take two eggs.
Oh, lovely colour, look at this.
To be a little bit naughty, I take just the yolk, and we beat it.
To this, you don't add any, any, any cream.
Absolutely forbidden.
So this is the beginning of the sauce.
So we put a little bit of parmesan.
In Roma, they use also pecorino cheese, which is a cheese to be grated.
There are fresh pecorino and aged pecorino.
But it's lovely to have a little bit of this.
Abundant pepper.
And another stir.
And this is the sauce.
I wouldn't put any salt here because the bacon here is quite salty, it's preserved.
We reduce it a little bit because I'm going to see what the pasta does.
I can see it is still stiff.
So I put it back again another three or four minutes.
Now here's the bacon that has produced also quite a lot of fat.
Should you be not wanting the fat, I show you a little trick.
Here we are.
And do this.
You absorb a little bit of the fat, and you take it off like this.
Very simple.
So the pasta seems to be doing well here, the taste now should be enough.
I switched off the guanciale because it's too hot and this is exactly what I don't want to be too hot.
So now I take the pasta and I put it into the, yes, that.
And you flavour it like this.
You let it cool down in doing this.
And it shouldn't be too hot because what is going to happen now should be the temperature enough to coat the egg around the pasta.
And now it comes, yes, the resistance, the actual sauce.
There you are.
And now we stir it like this.
You see usually by this stage the heat is so much in the wrong cooking that the eggs become scrambled eggs.
Not too scrambly.
And this is the carbonara.
And now the last touch, which is the embellishment.
Parmesan or pecorino, depending what you like.
And in my opinion also a nice touch of pepper.
This is decoration for me.
And this is the real carbonara.
The only one.
And it's exactly how it should be.
Creamy, without adding cream because this is the usual thing.
Like this is just fantastic.
Cameraman, everybody, you should taste it.
It's just wonderful.

steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
In a bowl, beat two egg yolks (for two people) and add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper.
Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly.
Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Stir the pasta until the sauce is creamy and coats the pasta evenly.
Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper for decoration.

subgoal_summaries.title: Cook Pasta-1
outcome: Spaghettoni is cooked and ready for the next step
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter. Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: Salt is added to the water to enhance the flavor of the pasta. Stirring prevents the pasta from sticking together.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Do not add oil to the water as it is unnecessary and can prevent sauce from sticking to the pasta.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Meat-2
outcome: Guanciale releases fat
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks. Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The guanciale releases fat which is used as a base for the sauce.
subgoal_summaries.tips: If you don't want too much fat, you can absorb some of it with a paper towel.

subgoal_summaries.title: Prepare Egg Mixture-3
outcome: A mixture of beaten egg yolks, cheese, and pepper
subgoal_summaries.instructions: In a bowl, beat two egg yolks and add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: This mixture forms the base of the sauce for Carbonara, providing richness and flavor without the use of cream.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Do not add any cream to the mixture as it is not part of the traditional recipe.

subgoal_summaries.title: Combine Pasta and Meat-4
outcome: Pasta is mixed with guanciale and cooled slightly
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: It shouldn't be too hot because the temperature should be enough to coat the egg around the pasta.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the guanciale is not too hot to prevent scrambling the eggs later.

subgoal_summaries.title: Add Egg Mixture-5
outcome: Pasta is coated with the egg mixture without scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The pasta should not be too hot when mixed with the egg mixture to prevent the eggs from scrambling, allowing them to coat the pasta smoothly.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Ensure the pasta has cooled down sufficiently before adding the egg mixture to prevent scrambling.

subgoal_summaries.title: Garnish and Serve-6
outcome: Pasta Carbonara is served with additional grated cheese and pepper for decoration.
subgoal_summaries.instructions: Serve the pasta with additional grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and a touch of pepper for decoration.
subgoal_summaries.explanation: The additional cheese and pepper serve as decoration and enhance the flavor of the dish.
subgoal_summaries.tips: Choose between parmesan or pecorino based on personal preference for the final touch.

subgoal_definitions.title: Gather Ingredients
subgoal_definitions.description: Collect all necessary ingredients for making Pasta Carbonara, including bacon or guanciale, cheese, eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.
original_steps: Gather the ingredients: guanciale (or pancetta), pecorino romano cheese, free-range organic eggs, pasta, black pepper, and optionally garlic.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Meat
subgoal_definitions.description: Chop the meat into small pieces, cook until crispy, and optionally add garlic for flavor.
original_steps: Cut guanciale (or pancetta) into chunks.
Heat olive oil in a pan and cook the guanciale until it releases fat.
Prepare the guanciale by removing the skin and slicing it into 1 cm thick pieces, then chop into 0.5 cm chunks.
Place the guanciale in a cold pan and turn the heat to medium-high to render the fat.
Crack a garlic clove and add it to the pan with the guanciale to infuse flavor.
Once the guanciale is golden, remove the garlic from the pan.
Cut about half a pound of thick-cut bacon into three-quarter inch pieces.
Heat a pan over medium heat and add a tiny bit of olive oil.
Add the bacon to the pan and slowly render out the fat until the bacon is crispy.
Once the bacon is crispy, remove some for garnish and drain most of the fat, leaving about two tablespoons in the pan.
Chop bacon into small pieces.
Cook the bacon in a pan until crispy, then turn off the heat and let it cool slightly.

subgoal_definitions.title: Prepare Egg Mixture
subgoal_definitions.description: Grate the cheese and mix it with eggs and black pepper to create the egg mixture.
original_steps: In a bowl, beat two egg yolks (for two people) and add grated parmesan or pecorino cheese and abundant pepper.
Crush black peppercorns using a pestle and mortar, then sift to use the hotter inner part of the peppercorns.
Crack eggs into a bowl and add about 20 grams of pecorino cheese, then whisk together.
Grate three ounces each of Pecorino Romano and Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese.
In a bowl, whisk together three whole eggs and two egg yolks.
Whisk the grated cheese into the egg mixture until combined.
Add freshly ground black pepper to the egg and cheese mixture to taste.
Separate egg yolks from egg whites and place the yolks in a bowl.
Grate pecorino romano cheese and add it to the egg yolks.
Add black pepper to the egg yolk and cheese mixture and mix well.

subgoal_definitions.title: Cook Pasta
subgoal_definitions.description: Boil salted water and cook the pasta until al dente, reserving some pasta water for later use.
original_steps: Boil water and add salt at a ratio of 10 grams per liter.
Add spaghettoni to the boiling water and cook for about 10 minutes, stirring occasionally.
Boil water for the pasta, adding a small amount of salt.
Twist the pasta into the boiling water to prevent sticking and cook for 8 minutes.
Boil about four quarts of water and add a tablespoon of kosher salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until slightly al dente, about 10 minutes.
Boil water in a pot and add salt.
Cook spaghetti in the boiling water until al dente.
Reserve some pasta water before draining the spaghetti.

subgoal_definitions.title: Combine Pasta and Meat
subgoal_definitions.description: Mix the cooked pasta with the prepared meat in the pan, adding some reserved pasta water to create an emulsion.
original_steps: Once the pasta is cooked, drain it and add it to the pan with guanciale, allowing it to cool slightly.
Turn off the heat under the guanciale and add the cooked pasta directly from the pot to the pan, including some pasta water.
Stir the pasta with the guanciale and fat, adding more pasta water to create an emulsion.

subgoal_definitions.title: Add Egg Mixture
subgoal_definitions.description: Off the heat, add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta, stirring quickly to form a creamy sauce, and adjust with more pasta water if needed.
original_steps: Mix the pasta with the egg mixture, ensuring the pasta is not too hot to avoid scrambling the eggs.
Stir the pasta until the sauce is creamy and coats the pasta evenly.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the pasta off the heat, stirring quickly to create a creamy sauce without scrambling the eggs.
Turn off the heat under the bacon pan and add the cooked spaghetti to the pan.
Add the egg and cheese mixture to the spaghetti, stirring gently to coat the pasta without scrambling the eggs.
If needed, add a little reserved pasta water to achieve a creamy consistency.
Add a small amount of reserved pasta water to the egg yolk and cheese mixture to help melt the cheese.
Transfer the cooked spaghetti directly from the pot to the pan with bacon.
Mix the spaghetti with the bacon and then add the egg yolk mixture, stirring quickly to coat the pasta and create a creamy sauce.
Add more reserved pasta water if needed to achieve the desired sauce consistency.

subgoal_definitions.title: Garnish and Serve
subgoal_definitions.description: Finish the dish by garnishing with additional cheese and black pepper before serving.
original_steps: Serve with additional grated parmesan or pecorino and a touch of pepper for decoration.
Finish the dish with additional cracked black pepper and a sprinkle of pecorino cheese before serving.
Plate the pasta and garnish with additional grated cheese and crispy bacon.
Finish with additional black pepper and grated pecorino romano cheese before serving.

approach_4.title: Additional Tips
